Thanks! For PREP - it doesn‚Äôt use CREATE2 (That‚Äôs why it can have the exact same address on all chains, including ZKSync which was usually an issue since their CREATE2 derives differently).

The accounts themselves can be upgraded by the user - they‚Äôre even modular (ERC-7579) so you can install new modules on them. The only thing you need to know to ‚Äúdiscover‚Äù the address is the initial configuration with which the account was deployed (which is usually a pairing of accountVersion + owner). 

Discovering the address derivations when not all users created wallets from the same initial config can be tricky though, it‚Äôs an active area of research we‚Äôre working on.

As for multichain syncing - the accounts can go out of sync. Some proposed solutions for this included having a Keystore Rollup (proposed by Vitalik iirc) which would be used as the source of ‚Äútruth‚Äù of the account config.

Hey all! 

We made EIP-7702 work with Resource Locks! The users can now prove that they don‚Äôt know the private key associated with the EIP-7702 account! 

This results in a true multichain account which has the *same* address on all EVM chains, even with non-standard CREATE2 implementations (like ZKSync, Abstract, etc‚Ä¶)! 

We also built-in protections for frontrunning on multiple chains in the cryptographic derivation itself - meaning that the user will always be able to deploy the account with the same configuration on all chains!

Beyond this, these accounts can have time locks, resource locks, multi-sigs and all other permission reductions which were impossible with normal EIP-7702 due to the existance of the private key! 

We call this method of deploying PREP - Provably Rootless EIP-7702 Proxy!

It‚Äôs 80% cheaper to deploy accounts this way as well!

We did all of this by packing additional protections within the r,s,v values of the signature itslef!

Would love feedback on this!

I just want to give a shout out to Ankit's excellent thread on the different models for resource locks. This feels extremely useful ahead of today's interop call. 

This part I want to highlight about how intents (and standards like ERC-7683) work with resource locks (I'm quoting Ankit here): 

"Intents use Solvers that take on risk by fulfilling transactions before finality" --> this is intents without resource locks.

"[Resource locks are an] out-of-protocol solution for finality and equivocation protection" --> aka resource locks allow solvers to be even faster (no need to wait for any origin chain confirmation), and even more confident they won't get rugged (no reorg risk on origin chain). 

The one potential downside to resource locks is the onboarding experience‚Äîusers need to onboard their funds or their account into a resource lock structure (and 7702 doesn't help here, unfortunately). Personally I'm unsure of now big/small this UX hurdle will be... but I'm really excited to see if it can be solved.

Any way you cut this, intents (including standards like ERC-7683) and resource locks work great together. (And as an FYI, Across recently upgraded its production contracts to be fully compatible with all types of resource lock models).

The exact details of how it is kept honest seemed excessive since the discussion was about atomic swaps, but I assume you'd agree that OP interop messaging does not require trusting the sequencer.

I didn't want to get into the full details of how FP works, just made the point that the sequencer is not "trusted" since it can be kept honest (in response to https://t.me/c/2276686237/1376 and https://t.me/c/2276686237/1374).  And therefore I claimed that it's possible to implement atomic swaps between OP chains using OP stack interop without HTLC by using messages.

To clarify, "anybody can submit a fault proof" really only has to do with the bridge. You don't submit a fault proof to the L2 client software, the L2 client software fully validates the chains and reorgs out blocks that contain invalid cross chain messages. If a user submits a claim about the L2 state to the bridge that is produced by malicous software, this claim can be contested and will not finalize. The same chain rules are enforced both within the fork choice rule in the client software as well as in the proof program, which is what is legible to the onchain bridge
Another recent implementation of Atomic Swaps (already in production) is 1inch Fusion+ https://1inch.io/assets/1inch-fusion-plus.pdf.
I beiieve https://x.com/atomiqlabs does a great job at quite atomic btc swaps

Rollup sequencers are not trusted to adhere to consensus rules.  They can get slashed on L1 if they cheat, their blocks get reorged out and someone else could continue the correct chain.  I don't consider this to be perfect and I demonstrated some attacks in the past, but I wouldn't go so far as to call them "trusted".

Just to give an example - consider swaps inside the OP superchain using Optimism's in-cluster interop protocol.  Instead of HTLC it would use fast cross-L2 messaging.  The swap is still atomic.  Either you get your tokens on chain A or you get it on chain B.  If the sequencer breaks this guarantee, anyone can submit a fault proof since the chain forked away from its rules.  Would you not call this atomic swaps?

I think we can agree that Atomic Swaps revolve around the concept of P2P trustless asset exchange, where either party receives their funds at the requested destination or gets their funds back. HTLCs are the most common implementation of this mechanism.
Other here referring to rollup sequencers.
Which "other"?  And my definition of Atomic Swaps does assume the system is permissionless.
The difference being is that one tries to be permissionless while the other has not fully figured that out yet.
I believe  https://spark.info uses Atomic Swaps, but not with HTLC contracts

By Atomic Swaps I'm referring to crosschain transfers, not same-chain swaps like Uniswap.  And they're atomic in the sense that both sides are guaranteed to get either their original funds or the funds on the other chain.  HTLC is one way to achieve this.  Uniswap isn't (and never meant to be).  But if a non-HTLC model achieves the above guarantee, would you not call it Atomic Swaps?
btw, the verification game in optimistic rollups uses similar liveness protection. One side could hold up the process for a while but at an economic cost, and ultimately the right thing will happen.

Atomic Swaps have for a long time exclusively referred to HTLCs since otherwise any swap is an atomic swap.

Uniswap is an atomic swap, Across is an atomic swap, Curve is an atomic swap, Balancer is an atomic swap, Stargate is an atomic swap. 

Personally, I am for preserving atomic swaps for HTLCs or similar ideas to make the space easier to understand.

In the same sense that if you trusted the sequencer of an optimistic rollup, you wouldn't need a bond. But they place a bond and incentivize anyone to submit a fraud proof if they misbehave. If you consider TRAIN solvers as "trusted" then you have to also consider optimistic rollups the same way.

You make a valid point, but it's not exactly about 'trust.' When we refer to 'trust,' we assume that you blindly send assets and trust the Solver to fulfill the transaction. That's not the case here. 

The bond serves as an economic enforcement mechanism on the Solver's side, ensuring they complete the transaction automatically. If they fail to do so, the user can always finalize it manually. It is also ecnomic incetnrive for other Solvers, to slash the original lazy one üòÇ

Yes, TRAIN could leverage of what I'm building on L2 chains and still support L1-L1 the way it does now.  A bit hard to describe the whole design in telegram messages but I'll share when I have something.  Happy to collaborate.

> Atomic Swaps use HTLCs.

Is there a trade mark on "Atomic Swaps" which I was not aware of?  I consider atomic swaps to be an idea, and HTLC is one way to implement it.  There are other ways, especially when the chain supports smart contracts.

> Layerswap and Train uses HTLCs.

Specific implementations. Not synonymous with Atomic Swaps.

> HTLCs will always be asymmetrical. Including Layerswap, Train, preHTLC, etc. If you make it the solver's problem does not make it less of a problem.

Since I haven't published anything yet and my design does not use the classic HTLC, I'll refer to TRAIN for this argument.  My understanding of TRAIN (@bot_insane can correct me if I'm wrong) is that the user funds are not held for the duration of the HTLC if the solver doesn't release them. Another solver can step in, give the funds to the user immediately, and slash the original solver to receive both the locked funds and the bond.  User funds are therefore safe and unlikely to be delayed as long as there's one solver willing to take the deal.  Doesn't this make it less of a problem?

> On last point, I thought the discussion I replied to was atomic swaps vs resource locks.

A system like the above combines the two.  It's atomic swaps but not exactly HTLC, and involves locking resources.  The design space is wide and still largely unexplored.

Yes, TRAIN does not leverage the fact that L1-L2s actually share a common truth. I am curious‚Äîwould it be possible to have a dual-mode system, and would your design be compatible with ours if we could leverage the fact that L1-L2s share a common truth while still falling back to preHTLCs for other chains?

If it's too early for this question, that's fine. Please just share any relevant materials, and I'll dig deeper.
As the old quote goes "Nothing Is More Powerful Than an Idea Whose Time Has Come" :)

Right, in TRAIN it would be the dapp.  My design is focused on Ethereum and the L2 ecosystem so I can make certain assumptions that TRAIN doesn't (in exchange for not supporting cross-L1 transfers).  TRAIN seems like the correct design for supporting chains with no shared source of truth.  And it's exciting to see an implementation on so many networks!

Atomic Swaps use HTLCs.
Layerswap and Train uses HTLCs.

HTLCs will always be asymmetrical. Including Layerswap, Train, preHTLC, etc. If you make it the solver's problem does not make it less of a problem.

Having solvers lock bonds to participate in HTLCs is still a HTLC. It is even a very common way to build scalable HTLCs since otherwise the system requires trust.

I would love to read the docs for system that does away with commitment ordering but I have seen no proof of one so far.

On last point, I thought the discussion I replied to was atomic swaps vs resource locks.

I've been working on something a bit similar, though with different design goals and therefore making different trade offs.  But the slashing mechanism is quite similar.  I'll share a writeup when I have something.

If I understand correctly, in TRAIN there is no offchain communication between the user and the solver, correct?  The solver transacts on both chains (locking funds on the destination chain and claiming them on the source chains.  The wallet verifies the state of the destination chain via a light client to ensure that the solver locked funds for the same secret.  As long as the wallet can trust the state, the process is trustless.  At most, the solver can lock up funds for the lock duration, but gets slashed for it by whoever solves the intent instead. Right?

I know. You have a specific intents network design in mind. But my comment was that there will be protocols that don't work that way.  As long as there's a single protocol that is permissionless, a single greedy solver can break social consensus and help transfer illicit funds.  (and I'd like to make sure that there will be at least one such protocol for the sake of censorship resistance)

I'm sure you're knowledgeable in this space but please don't assume we're all morons. Some of us have been working on these problems for some years, and have been thinking about these problems as well.

I'm kinda familiar with how resource locks and atomic swaps work :)  I'm also well familiar with how HTLC works but don't assume that atomic swaps == HTLC.  Note that I said "atomic swaps", not "HTLC.  And remember HTLC was designed for networks that don't have smart contracts.  Our design space is wider and we can fix asymmetries.

To give a simple example, consider something similar to HTLC but with the solver having to lock a bond (much larger than each individual swap). If the solver holds up user funds, it can be proven on chain and slash the solver.  So yes, the solver can hold up user funds but at a high economic cost.  The user gets the funds back after the delay but also gets additional funds from whoever caused the delay.  In addition, HTLC requires 1:1 relations.  Atomic swaps - not necessarily in the first step, until both sides are committed (which can then be proven on chain).

> Argue: The allocator has the power to delay user's access to funds. Though this lock is weaker than the HTLC lock.

This is a fundamental misunderstanding of resource locks and locked funds in general.

Atomic swaps, or hashed timelock swaps, fundamentally and asymmetrically locks funds. Either party in a HTLC can cause the others funds to be locked until expiry.
Which then have to be manually recovered. 

For resource lock flows, nobody can lock the user's funds because they themselves have already decided to lock the funds. Using an intent bridge that supports resource locks is no different from not using that intent bridge at all.
At no point does any solver have any power over the user, unlike HTLCs.

Argue: The allocator has the power to delay user's access to funds. Though this lock is weaker than the HTLC lock.

I actually have a slightly diff position here:
1. Fast/small transfers, use intents
2. Larger txs/rebalancing, use underlying L2-L2 mechanism (which should wait for some notion of finality - perhaps bonded with preconfers)

For fast (and probably small) transfers it can be L2-L2 coordination. For larger amounts it's safer to settle on via the L1 bridges to ensure L2 finality (fraud/fault proofs and all). We need both but the L1-L2 standard ETH bridge seems like the minimum requirement.
Yep! L2-L2 would need some coordination between rollups, but this becomes a LOT easier to solve (and paves the way for Espresso, Javelin, based rollups, etc.)

Exactly. And it doesn't involve ACD since it should be a RIP rather than an EIP.

We just need a standard interface for an L1 contract that every rollup should deploy, which uses the rollup's canonical bridge to send ETH to L2. The address of this standardized ETH bridge should be a part of the rollup's on-chain config contract.

Wallets that transact with a chain-specific address on a yet-unknown L2 can use this to "bootstrap" - transferring ETH to the rollup and using the RPC from the rollup's on-chain config to start transacting there. It's the bare minimum the wallet needs to start using an unknown L2.

My 2 wei on gradual approach to getting buy-in for the Eth messaging standard:

Message format (define common message packet) ->
Messaging interface(standardize sendMessage() and handleMessage()  interfaces for sending and receiving messages) -> 
Support for transport-agnostic proofs - a) Sending side proofs (how various proof types can be attached to messages) , b) Receiving side proofs (how proofs can be verified so only valid messages can be accepted without relying on bridges)

The HTLC protocol can implement RIP-7789 to guarantee reorg protection across ETH forks.

Waiting an arbitrary amount of time also works but is a probabilistic guarantee.

In short, when you request a 1 ETH swap from Arbitrum to Optimism, the solver locks 1.2 ETH for the swap. If the user releases the destination lock, they will receive 1.2 ETH. If the LP does, the user will receive 1 ETH. This incentivizes LPs to act. Additionally, this creates a window for MEV-like bots to detect these scenarios and capture rewards.

Practically speaking, intent settlement latency is a factor here. 

If settlement latency is long (e.g. 2 hours), in practice we'd expect the fill to have occurred already.
That's a concern for any cross-chain operation, but in this case, you have an option as user for wait more than 10seconds, then lock the funds.

2) user generates s and hash(s) and locks funds in the source chain
3) solver detects this, locks funds in the destination chain with hash(s)
4) user verifies that funds are indeed locked (with Light Client)
5) releases the s to Solver, to unlock funds

it depends on the requirements of the system. In the bridge design we presented, we favour moving the funds towards the destination chain on the slow path. This has the benefit of keeping all of the liquidity on the shared layer (embedded rollup or L1). However, if we want to favour fast source-chain release, we would only need the L1 or embedded rollup to include the solution. As L2s are reading from this shared state, source chain release can be as fast as destination chain delivery:

source L2: transfer request.
shared layer: post solution
source L2: observe solution on shared layer, release funds
destination L2: observe solution on shared layer, mint/deliver funds

to the point on "not interop broadly", as Vitalik mentioned, token movement is 80% of the use cases we're interested in, although I'm sure we could address other cases using the shared layer for other functionality, e.g. shared key-value stores

Our most recent research has been on embedding rollups in other rollups: embedding= maintaining a local view of an embedded rollup's state in the embedding rollup by reading embedded rollup batches/updates/roots from L1. This allows embedding rollups to get all the benefits of reading from shared state without the need to send L1 transactions. 1st of 2 articles on embedded rollups here: https://ethresear.ch/t/embedded-rollups-part-1-introduction/21460

For me, the core driving principle of L2 interop is:

Now light client verification

1. _Any_ cross-L2 proof application, as well as things like keystore wallets, is going to have a "L2 verifying L1 state" component
2. You _could_ do this by just reading the L1 state root (L2s already gave access to recent L1 state roots, because they need to process deposits, though maybe they need to expose them to the VM). But that costs a lot of gas and a lot of data, eg. a merkle proof is 1000 bytes, prohibitive on L2 esp in a future where other L2 ops can be hyper-optimized. You _could_ SNARK it, but that's a lot of execution, and it adds complexity to add aggregation protocols etc. We want the process of L2 reading L1 to be zero cost, in terms of execution and in terms of calldata
3. L1SLOAD and REMOTESTATICCALL are very convenient form factors for doing this
4. In addition to this, there are specific applications where, today, we are losing a lot by inefficiently duplicating data across multiple L2s (cough cough oracles...). L1SLOAD / REMOTESTATICCALL fix this

Hey all üëã

One thing we at Polymer would like to see standardized is that (and how) L2s maintain a view within their execution environment of the L1 state they  derive from.

This is already done in op-stack both by means of the L1Block contract and an EIP-4788 ring buffer. To my knowledge no other L2 stack does this yet. Honestly this- being able to compose with arbitrary L1 state- seems like it should be a basic requirement to even be considered an L2.

Ideally we would agree on a standard like EIP-4788 that is totally stack agnostic both politically and technically. But there are some complications around and inefficiencies to using beacon block hashes to verify execution state claims. In that case, I recommend we introduce a new standard ‚ÄúRIP-4788‚Äù which is the same ring buffer predeploy construction but instead of storing beacon block roots it stores execution block header hashes.

These commitments to the L1 inside the L2 are broadly useful for introp and composability. It is useful for RIP-7755, RIP-7789, RIP-7728, ERC-3668, verifying AVS validator set state on the L1 for purposes of EigenDA or Lagrange state committees or other AVS protocols, and anything else that needs to verify arbitrary L1 state inside the L2.

The other thing we would like to see standardized around is the support for an extended EIP-2935 ring buffer of historic L2 blockhashes inside the L2 execution environment. Ideally the ring buffer would be large enough to span the settlement frequency of the L2 on the L1 so that the sparse set of L2 outputs on the L1 provides complete coverage of all historic L2 blocks. This would let the L1 verify any claims about not just historic L2 state through the sparse L2 outputs on the L1 but, importantly, also verify claims about any L2 txs and receipts (logs/events).

In combination these two things would let L2s that settle and derive from Ethereum to verify arbitrary claims about Ethereum and all of the other L2s that settle to Ethereum.

We can throw together an RIP for this but since it is more-or-less just coordinating around existing EIPs I am not sure if this is necessary. Would appreciate any feedback on this.
